items.text: **Rocky Mountain Construction** (also abbreviated as **RMC**) is a manufacturing and construction company based in [[LINK|lang_en|Hayden,_Idaho|Hayden, Idaho]], [[LINK|lang_en|United_States|United States]]. The company is best known for its I-Box track and Topper Track for [[LINK|lang_en|Wooden_roller_coaster|wooden roller coasters]].
In 2001, Rocky Mountain Construction was established by Fred Grubb and Suanne Dedmon.

Fred Grubb previously had experience in the construction industry having worked on [[LINK|lang_en|Custom_home|custom homes]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Zoo|zoo]] exhibits. The company has worked on several projects including the construction of [[LINK|lang_en|Roller_coaster|roller coasters]], [[LINK|lang_en|Water_park|water parks]], [[LINK|lang_en|Steel_building|steel buildings]], [[LINK|lang_en|Miniature_golf|miniature golf courses]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Go-kart|go kart tracks]]. [[CITE|47|http://rockymtnconstruction.com/about.html]]

In 2009 [[LINK|lang_en|Alan_Schilke|Alan Schilke]] of Ride Centerline began providing design and engineering work for Rocky Mountain Construction. He previously worked with [[LINK|lang_en|Arrow_Dynamics|Arrow Dynamics]] (later [[LINK|lang_en|S&S_Worldwide|S&S Worldwide]]) to design [[LINK|lang_en|Tennessee_Tornado|Tennessee Tornado]], [[LINK|lang_en|Road_Runner_Express_(Six_Flags_Fiesta_Texas)|Road Runner Express]], and [[LINK|lang_en|X_(roller_coaster)|X]]. Working with Rocky Mountain Construction, Schilke and Grubb designed the I-Box track for wooden roller coasters. The first installation of this track technology debuted on [[LINK|lang_en|New_Texas_Giant|New Texas Giant]] at [[LINK|lang_en|Six_Flags_Over_Texas|Six Flags Over Texas]] in 2011. [[CITE|7|http://prnewswire.com/news-releases/new-texas-giant-named-best-new-ride-of-2011-130029598.html]]
In late 2011, Schilke announced that the company would be working on two projects throughout 2012 which would both open in 2013.

These were later revealed to be an I-Box retrack of [[LINK|lang_en|The_Rattler_(roller_coaster)|The Rattler]] at [[LINK|lang_en|Six_Flags_Fiesta_Texas|Six Flags Fiesta Texas]] and a new roller coaster designed from scratch at [[LINK|lang_en|Silver_Dollar_City|Silver Dollar City]] named [[LINK|lang_en|Outlaw_Run|Outlaw Run]]. [[CITE|9|http://spokanejournal.com/article.php?id=7763]] The track technology used for Outlaw Run, which allows a square beam of wood to be twisted, took 4 years to develop. It allows Rocky Mountain Construction to design layouts with maneuvers that are not traditionally possible with wooden roller coasters such as heartline rolls. Grubb has stated the technology could be used for new elements in the future. Some new elements were realized with the announcement of *[[LINK|lang_en|Goliath_(Six_Flags_Great_America)|Goliath]] * at [[LINK|lang_en|Six_Flags_Great_America|Six Flags Great America]]. The ride features a [[LINK|lang_en|Dive_loop|dive loop]] and a [[LINK|lang_en|Zero-g_roll|zero-g stall]]. The ride opened in June 2014. [[CITE|12|http://content.sixflags.com/comingin2014]]

In 2013, Rocky Mountain Construction signed a deal with [[LINK|lang_en|Netherlands|Dutch]] amusement ride firm [[LINK|lang_en|Vekoma|Vekoma]]. The agreement allows Vekoma to sell Rocky Mountain Construction's roller coasters outside the North American market. In 2014, [[LINK|lang_en|Kolmården_Wildlife_Park|Kolmården Wildlife Park]] in Sweden announced plans to build the first Rocky Mountain coaster in Europe called *Wildfire*, which opened on May 1, 2016.
To cope with demand, Rocky Mountain Construction opened a new factory, twice the size of their existing one, in August 2014.

sentences.text: I-Box Track (also known as Iron Horse Track) – Rocky Mountain Construction's most common product. A formation of steel track for wooden roller coasters. The first installation of this track was on New [[LINK|lang_en|Texas_Giant|Texas Giant]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Six_Flags_Over_Texas|Six Flags Over Texas]]. [[CITE|16|http://amusementtoday.com/backissues/at_may_2011_web.pdf]] [[CITE|17|http://parkworld-online.com/news/fullstory.php/aid/1736/Steel_track_for_wooden_coasters.html]]

Topper Track – Having been installed on several coasters around the United States. [[CITE|18|http://facebook.com/media/set?set=a.154376687932793.23770.154373424599786&type=3]] [[CITE|19|http://content.sixflags.com/news/overgeorgia/rides/georgia-cyclone?gc=GTEST0000000002&ic=I0028E136]] [[CITE|20|http://newsplusnotes.blogspot.com.au/2011/03/two-six-flags-rides-receive-topper.html]] The track is designed to reduce the maintenance required for a wooden roller coaster and provide a smoother ride experience. [[CITE|19|http://content.sixflags.com/news/overgeorgia/rides/georgia-cyclone?gc=GTEST0000000002&ic=I0028E136]] [[CITE|21|http://coaster-net.com/blogs/160-rocky-mountain-construction-company]] This steel track replaces the upper layers of laminated wood. [[CITE|21|http://coaster-net.com/blogs/160-rocky-mountain-construction-company]]

Wooden roller coaster [[LINK|lang_en|Train_(roller_coaster)|trains]] – specifically designed to run on the company's own Topper Track, however, they could be added to other wooden roller coasters as well. The trains feature steel wheels as opposed to [[LINK|lang_en|Roller_coaster_wheel_assembly|polyurethane wheels found on most trains]]. [[CITE|9|http://spokanejournal.com/article.php?id=7763]]
T-Rex Track – Rocky Mountain Construction's first true steel roller coaster, the T-Rex track is a single rail track.
Raptor Track – Very similar to T-Rex track, but Raptor track only runs trains that are one seat wide instead of two seats wide, and tend to be smaller.

items.text: As of 2017, Rocky Mountain Construction has built or refurbished 16 [[LINK|lang_en|Roller_coaster|roller coasters]] around the world and all of them are currently operating with five coasters being constructed. [[CITE|31|https://rcdb.com/10583.htm]]
